India Is Suggesting Bengali & Sanskrit Names For A Lonely Exoplanet That Looks Like Earth's Sun

India Is Suggesting Bengali & Sanskrit Names For A Lonely Exoplanet That Looks Like Earth's Sun

The Astronomical Society in India is going to give a lonely exo-planet and its star a Bengali or a Sanskrit name.

Reports state that this newly discovered exoplanet outside the solar system is revolving around a lonely star called ‘HD 86081 b’.

Planets that go around stars other than the Sun are called exoplanets. Exoplanets may reflect the light of their parent star, but more often than not look dull owing to the brightness of their star.

However, this exoplanet is hotter, larger and a little older, as reported by Business Insider. Users in India can vote for their favourite name from a list of five.

The list has four Sanskrit names and one Bengali name to choose from.

Finding a name for a planet is a part of the International Astronomical Union (IAU) Name Exoplanets campaign called NameExoworlds,

India is giving Bengali, Sanskrit names to a lonely exoplanet and its starhttps://t.co/4WTWeV1o2f - by @pabsgill pic.twitter.com/uluzGCSn9h — Business Insider India🇮🇳 (@BiIndia) October 21, 2019

Students were invited to submit their suggestions for naming the astronomical objects currently being referred to as star HD 86081 and exoplanet HD86081

From the thousands of entries that came in, five names were shortlisted for each and they are Anahata, Bibha, Rashmirathi, Suteja, Vibhas..

The four Sanskrit names in the running are Anahata (Always present), Bibha (Lightbeam), Rashmirathi (Rider of the Sun’s chariot), Suteja (Bright) and Vibhas (Special light).

While the Jupiter-like exoplanet has one Bengali option and four Sanskrit names up for voting - Abhrakasin (Sheltered in clouds), Aleya (Will-o-the-wisp), Santamas (Clouded), Taptabrihas (Hot Jupiter) and Turanga (Divine horse).

Twitter

It was also reported that H86081b is the only planet circling the parent star. Also, the planet is positioned much closer to the star and it is way hotter.

HD 86081 is just another middling mediocre star, one among the billions of them. With a surface temperature of about 6000 K, it is 1.55 times bigger, 1.21 times massive and 1.75 times brighter than the Sun.

Public voting to select the names were opened on October 10. Voting will remain open till November 1, 2019, after which the final list of names will be sent to the International Astronomical Union (IAU).

The final results are scheduled to be announced by the international organization in December 2019.
